Posts.Content: Sep 19, 2008 01:57PM Route53 wrote: We are pursuing this path as well right now.   We have BCBS  1.2cm, grade 2 stage 1, er/pr+, her2-, negative nodes.  Would like to hear how much other people's costs were and how much insurance paid for.  The rep did take some financial information to see if they could help pay for it in case insurance said no.  Well here we hope for a low Oncotype score.  Route 53 http://route53.wordpress.com
Posts.Title: Oncotype DX ckern Coltsneck

Posts.Content: Sep 7, 2008 10:26PM - edited Sep 7, 2008 10:27PM by Route53 Fellow husband here.  Let me first say, that as someone who is also dealing with a diificult medical issue, I'm sure your wife will come to you once the initial shock is over. While my wife was not diagnosed with agressive cancer, Grade 2, we were a bit shocked at the thought of waiting 5 weeks to have the surgery.  5 weeks has seemed like both an eternity as well as the shortest 5 weeks in our lives. You might think you wish you had 5 weeks too, but my wife needed almost imstantly that she wanted a bi-lateral mastectomy even thought the physician said she was eligible for a single lumpectomy. Hopefully your wife will be taking this week to make her decision a well informed one.  I'm sure you will be a strong guide in all of this.  If  you do have time to get the second opinion, you should do so though.  Our physician offered us that chance and although my wife had tons of brochures with her of other medical groups with some incredible press and resumes, she had done her research and did not bother with second opinions. We are going in for surgery in 2 days and I'm glad the date is finally here. Route53 http://route53.wordpress.com
Posts.Title: Husband of "Just Diagnosed" meinny7 Mary-Lou

Posts.Content: Sep 25, 2008 12:49PM - edited Sep 25, 2008 01:09PM by Route53 Kevin, You and I are on the same timeframe although many things are different about our wive's situations.  It sounds like you've already been pretty good and active, I have a thread on things for husbands to do: http://community.breastcancer.org/forum/16/topic/720875?page=1 I'm sure you could add a few tidbits yourself.  For me she described it best the other night.  My wife hates horror movies and when it gets to the scary parts she closes her eyes and covers her ears. I become her eyes and ears and tell her what I heard the doctors say and just try to make it more palatable. I echo Shirlann.  Just tell them, "Things are moving along.  Its just one step at a time and we'll wait and see.  It's a long process" You can also read my blog which roughly mimicks your timeframe from a husband's persepective. http://route53.wordpress.com Good luck to you and here's to giving husband's a good name in these forums.  Really...we do care (in our own individual ways).  Route53
Posts.Title: How to support her KevinK 1Cathi

Posts.Content: Sep 15, 2008 12:19PM Route53 wrote: Sybil, Although we did not seek a second opinion, I think at this point you should get a second opinion based on your experience to date.  It will make you feel better at lease as you do not seem to have your mind made up.  More importantly, you need to feel confident with the decision.  In the end it is YOUR decision.  Fortunately my wife knew what she wasnted as soon as the doctor told her a lumpectomy was an option.  My wife also had dense breasts and said "I'm only going to go through this once", and chose a bilateral mastectomy with a total skin-sparing mastectomy and reconstruction. Good luck but I would recommend getting that second opinion for some peace of mind. Route53 http://route53.wordpress.com

Posts.Content: Sep 16, 2008 10:16PM Route53 wrote: Lynn, As a husband (and if I were your husband), I'd not want to read that yet as I am sure you tell him those words with your actions every day.  If he has been with you through this, he will continue to cry, laugh and fight with you every day.  We know you are hurting and trying to be tough and you know us husbands try and do the same. Sounds like there are some good things that can be done.  We are praying for you.  Route53 http://route53.wordpress.com
Posts.Title: A letter to my husband LynnW Route53

Posts.Content: Mar 13, 2009 03:20PM - edited Mar 13, 2009 04:49PM by Route53 Karen, My wife had the same feeling as you prior to surgery.  The had only one lump but had bilateral just so she wouldn't have to relive it again.  She had a low Oncotype score and was Her2-.  She is young (early 40s) and understood what side effects Tamoxifin would have.  She did not have any chemo or radiation either as it was not recommended.  The one thing as a statistician she understood the possibility of errors in Oncotype scoring which could easily have put her at a higher risk.  Her feeling was that for a slight inconvenience she would start Tamoxifin as part of a trial and if it got too much, she would stop, Dr. Hope Rugo who is one of the Medical advisors on this site helped my wife to understand that she'd still be able to live her life fully even with the Tamoxifin and my wife joined one of her clinical trials.  She told my wife she didn't need to do anything more but my wife had several thoughts: In the end, the choice is yours but I would wait until after your surgery before deciding as you still have other things that might show up or change your decision process. Erik (Route53) http:/route53.wordpress.com
Posts.Title: Anyone declining further treatment after bilateral? karen_3 Jamie6

Posts.Content: Route53 wrote: This forum says Before, "DURING" and After. Well my wife is currently 3 hours into her 5 hour surgery and I'm sitting here doing the one thing I was dreading.  I kidded the doctor to give me "what she's having" so I could get knocked out for a few hours. Well surprisingly the first 3 hours have been okay.  For those technically inclined, I highly recommend during the pre-surgery visits to ask if they have wireless computing.  It has enabled me to work here very productively while waiting.  Bring your cell phone of course to field all calls.  If cell phones aren't allowed, make sure to bring an iPod or other music player and some light reading, "People, Golf Digest, etc.".  The guy next to me is watching "Old School" on his DVD player.  Inappropriate I know, but if it takes the edge off, I guess it works. My stressed out wife was a little worried about me this morning and was a little in tears.  When she asked if I was going to be okay waiting.  I told her I thought so although, "The weather doesn't look good today, so I won't be able to play golf"  Yes it was a joke, but it relieved the tension. On a more serious note, I want to thank everyone on these boards.  Husbands always need support too and these forums with both husbands and wives has been a great support community for me.  You all rock and I look forward to moving on to the "After Surgery" forums tomorrow! Route53 http://route53.wordpress.com Route 53 http://route53.wordpress.com; Bilateral total skin sparing mastectomy w/ reconstruction Dx 7/26/2008, IDC, 1cm, Stage I, Grade 2, 0/2 nodes, ER+/PR+, HER2- Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: What to do while in the waiting room! Route53 Route53

Posts.Content: Sep 15, 2008 05:48AM - edited Sep 15, 2008 08:28PM by Route53 Beth,  I'm happy to say my wife is home and has taken herelf off of the Vicodin.  They removed 2 lymph nodes and we are now waiting for the pathology report. We took her first walk around the block today, I washed her hair, and got everything ready for the work week I have to return to tomorrow. To all of you on this posting.  Thanks for your stories. To the woman who let her husband and son go to a movie, I bet they'll have to see it again as I don't even know how I could occupy myself.  If any of you want to know a bit about the pre and post-surgery thoughts I have been keeping a blog that you can find in my signature below Route 53 http://route53.wordpress.com

Posts.Content: Sep 18, 2008 01:07AM - edited Sep 18, 2008 01:09AM by Route53 Thanks "Girls"...I was afraid nobody would respond.  So, did you look?  How far along did you look?  And when exactly did you reveal to your Significant others? My wife is supposed to get 4 "fills" on consecutive weeks beginning two weeks after surgery. So did you let them look sometime during this timeframe? Again she started at a DD, so I'm guessing she'll look pretty "puggish" Route53 http://route53.wordpress.com
Posts.Title: Getting your first peek after Skin Sparing Mastectomy Route53 Route53

Posts.Content: Sep 18, 2008 06:10PM - edited Sep 21, 2008 05:41AM by Route53 Hi Kerry, just for clarification, this thread is really based upon my wife asking me to seek other women's advice on when best to look.  As we are both children of physicians we both have seen how people are affected visually by outcomes before they are prepared.  It's more about her, not me. Everyone and every relationship is different and as her primary caregiver I still have to do both micro and macro-life managing.  Macro-managing my wife's overall emotion does require micromanaging her expectations as well unfortunately.  This is a very up and down time for most women as you know and I am trying to help her fight those momentary bouts of depression.  As you signature says, Go Hard or Go Home.  Well as much as I personally am in to giving it your all sometimes...my wife has gone hard for a while but every once in a while she breaks down and you have to be there. I am personally not going to look until she wants me to look.  What she is looking for is just a baseline from other women as to when they were ready to look and maybe if there was a proper time to take a look without being too shocked.  She's already flipflopped on whether she wants me to see, and I told her what ever she wants is up to her.  Again, she is just looking for some opinions based upon what other women say.  Many say, "when she's ready", but she'd like to know when other women thought that was for them. NJNative- thanks she's actually surprised she's not feeling any loss for her girls.  Maybe it is because she still has the outer skin.  Thanks for your insight. Next Tuesday will be two weeks and after her drains are taken out.  She told me she thinks that might be too early for her.  yes, this is very good in the larger scheme of things,  Very fortunate.
Posts.Title: Getting your first peek after Skin Sparing Mastectomy Route53 Route53

Posts.Content: Route53 wrote: I don't know how to put this delicately, so I'll just ask it.  After you've had a total skin sparing mastectomy, when was the first time you actually goot a look at yourself after the bandages were taken off (how long after the surgery)?  My wife was a DD and we are just wondering what this is going to look like or if we even want to look?  Is the skin just laying there?  We've seen all the photos of final results after the expanders have been inflated, but are wondering if this is somethin we are't going to want to look at until she's inflated to at least a B size?  Anyone have advice or past experience? Route53 http://route53.wordpress.com Route 53 http://route53.wordpress.com; Bilateral total skin sparing mastectomy w/ reconstruction Dx 7/26/2008, IDC, 1cm, Stage I, Grade 2, 0/2 nodes, ER+/PR+, HER2- Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Getting your first peek after Skin Sparing Mastectomy Route53 Route53

Posts.Content: Sep 18, 2008 10:01PM - edited Sep 18, 2008 10:02PM by Route53 Well we just got back from our first post-op appt. and well we both got a look.  I was talking to the surgeon as she had her back to me as she was replacing the bandages.  My wife had her hands in front of her face. Well the surgeon moved and I saw.  It was nowhere near what I thought it would be like.  When I told the physician about this thread, she smiled and said that is one of the most often asked post-surgery questions.  She said she tells people it looks like a dried apple.  I told her about RoseG saying it looked like a pug dog and she and the nurse both said they were going to use that in the future. My impression was that it more looked like a melting sundae.  When my wife saw my eyes, she dropped her hands and looked.  We both said it wasn't anywhere near what we thought.  So here we are on day 9 and we're both a lot more relieved. The drains are still in though as we meet with the ps tomorrow and the nurse said that he might take it out Route53 http://route53.wordpress.com

Posts.Title: How Long in Hospital after Bi-Later with Reconstruction? Mocity mom_of_2

Posts.Content: Sep 21, 2008 05:40AM Route53 wrote: Morning, that is a great way to look at it and so very true. Well morning, I have to tell you.  My respect and love for all the women on this board is mutual.  I've always said it is the spirit in a woman that shines through the brightest and attracts me.  My wife laughs when she always used to point at a gorgeous young actress like girl with a grimace on her face and I would say she wasn't attractive to me.  Any woman who has gone through what all of you are going through has an inner fortitude and strength that is very attractive.  As far as women who must go through this alone, I'm all the more in awe.  This morning my wife woke up to a leaky drain and we had blood everywhere.  The calmness my wife exhibited was amazing.  I think I needed the Atavin.  The way she handled the situation was amazing.  I've known my wife for almost 25 years and the strength she showed this morning was  truly something I'd never ever seen from her. Ironically, I used to work for a cruise line that developed the concept of "escorts".  We were a luxury line and most women were traveling alone as in many cases they were divorced or their husbands were deceased.  The women outnumbered the men 8 to 1.  We hired widowers and trained them in manners and gave them dance lessons as well as history lessons and sent them on cruises as paid "escorts to dance, eat with and go on tours.  They were required to dance no more than two dances in a row with the ladies, etc. Okay....can't figure out how that would work here...but..just thought I'd lighten things up a bit. I know what you mean about people who are dying.   I was a young freshman in college when I met a grad student named Randy Pausch.  We drove home and back to school in a car for 4 hours each way one Thanksgiving and I will never forget that first meeting.  Randy was the Carnegie Mellon Professor who wrote "The Last Lecture" while he was dying and leaving behind a young family.  Watch him die this year was one of the most humbling and inspirational things in my life. Route53 http://route53.wordpress.com

Posts.Content: Aug 4, 2009 07:02PM Route53 wrote: My wife (MarketingMom) is the woman in the pictures in this article along with Dr. Hwand and the Decision Support Rep.  Let me first say, it is an option and we consented to haveing a rep in the meetings.  This clinic is very open to providing you with all the choices and to help you make the decisions. What we really found useful was the way communication was managed.  Appointments are stressful.  We all want answers and are listening with a biased ear.  My wife knew that she would only be listening to the terrible stuff and brought me along to make sure that I would be able to provide her with all the pros and cons.  The Decisions Support Services group was always calling to make sure we had all the information we needed and that all of our questions were answered.  Before each appt, we crafted long questionnaires that were given to the physician ahead of time and she answered them all.  Decision Support Services then transcribed all of our meetings and gave us a copy at the end of each appointment. Sometimes when my wife and I disagreed about something the doctor mentioned, we were able to look at the notes.  It really saved us a lot of heartache and headaches. Now these services really empower the patient and help them move forward.  If you are a passive patient this might all seem a bit of a put off as if the doctor isn't taking responsibility.  On the contrary, the doctors will counter you if they think you are making the wrong decision.  When at first the physician told my wife about a lumpectomy, my wife immediately asked about a bliateral mastectomy and walked my wife through it all.  She didn't push my wife into one decision or another.  I read so much about how many women felt as though their doctor was walking them down a one lane path and I thik this helps alleviate that situation. Any downsides to this?  Well yes, your appointments might go longer and you might wait longer as some people have lots of questions, but the most important thing is that you get all the information that you need. Erik (Route53) http://route53.wordpress.com  "My wife's motto was I didn't choose cancer, it chose me. But I chose how I wanted to beat it."
Posts.Title: Lumpectomy with radiation, but no hormonal threrapy elimar PauldingMom

Posts.Content: Aug 8, 2009 12:51PM Route53 wrote: Yes Elimar,  To me the best part was their extensive note taking and supplying us with those notes as we left each appointment.  They really made sure we had a laundry list of questions submitted to our physician beforehand,  Man of the same questions we have here. How long will the surgery take?  When will I get my results?  Can I take radiation now? Etc.  These helped to make sure the questions were addressed whether we asked them directly or not...and then afterwards, any questions we had about what we thought the doctor had converyed were calrified and then we were able to make the most educated decisions. Erik (Route53) http://route53.wordpress.com

Posts.Content: Dec 28, 2008 11:49PM Route53 wrote: DDlatt, Yes the physician group you are with is the same as my wife's and my mother's.  They like to treat things as aggressively as they can.  They will take the risk factors that are given to you but incorporate the margins of error to make sure that not mistakes are made.  They do like to avoid ports from what I've noticed, but I'm not sure if that is a normal thing, Route53 http://route53.wordpress.com
Posts.Title: Starting chemo January 2009? lisalisa ktym

Posts.Content: Aug 24, 2009 02:40PM Route53 wrote: Elimar, The pronblem with the charts is that even though they say Tamoxifen witll reduce by 50% is that the original score reading has a large enough standadrd deviation that if you were pessimistic you could say that you were almost in a risky category.  My wife had a score of 10, but the possiblle error in the scoring could also put her at the same risk as your natural score. We were leaning away from Tamoxifen but my wife said that if she could just knock off a few points and do everything she could to make sure she could see her kids have kids, then the decison was easy.  My wife also volunteered to be part of a research test for those with low oncotype scores so that there would be a sample size worth measuring in her category. Erik (Route53) http://route53.wordpress.com
Posts.Title: Lumpectomy with radiation, but no hormonal threrapy elimar PauldingMom

Posts.Content: Nov 10, 2008 07:00PM Route53 wrote: Good question.  My wife was originally told she was a good candidate for a lumpectomy.  When my wife told the breast surgeon that she'd prefer a bilateral mastectomy, her physician did not flinch. My wife had made up her mind before.  A side note, as my wife made this decision she was not even thinking of reconstruction until the physician told her she could have this done in a single surgery. My wife felt fortunate that the cancer was detected and did not want to rely on luck again to save her life.  Since her mother had a bilateral mastectomy 20 years prior and my own mother had a single mastectomy 5 years prior, my wife felt this decision was a no brainer. Route53 http://route53.wordpress.com
Posts.Title: For those who "could" have Lumpectomy.... why choose Mast? Estepp sbmolee

Posts.Content: Sep 16, 2008 01:03AM - edited Sep 16, 2008 01:06AM by Route53 There is nothing like a personal referral.  If you know of anyone who has had breast cancer in your area, ask them.  Our OBGYN referred us to other people in her group.  We knew of some people who had gone to that group of surgeons, but my own mother had gone to another group and my wife liked my mother's physician and outcome.  It made my wife more comfortable and we were in a PPO  Can we ask where you live?  We live in the San Francisco area and had the choice of Cal Pacific Medical Center, Stanford or University of California at San Francisco (UCSF).  We chose UCSF and their Breast Care Center.. Route53 http//route53.wordpress.com.

Posts.Content: Nov 17, 2008 12:11PM Route53 wrote: MDempsey and Shanda, Sorry to hear.  When I hear stories like yours it just puts me back 4 short months ago when we found out and two short months ago when my wife had surgery.  Back then, time seemed to stand still but when we look back, time actually flew by. I'm not a doctor, but if either of you are anxious, your physician can prescribe something for you like they did for my wife although if you can avoid it and keep your nerves intact naturally through the support of friends and family, that is highly recommended. MDempsey, I highly recommend perusing these boards about telling your child.  You didn't mention their age, but there are lots of tips here.  Obviously you know your child best and how they will react.  I thik a lot of how they react will come from your delivery.  Strength comes from strength.  You will need her to be strong for you, so share what strength you have together. Good luck to both of you. Route53 (Erik) http://route53.wordpress.com

I'm guessing with larger breasts, my wife might have more to drain, but we'll see.  Already down to 40ccs. Good to know that the pathology report will be back then too. Posts.Title: Removing Drains and Getting Pathology Report Route53 hostanut

Posts.Content: Sep 18, 2008 11:14AM - edited Sep 19, 2008 09:56AM by Route53 I was reading another post last night in which some women said they had it in for more than 4 weeks.  In that same thread, it mentioned that a physician told the patient to start limiting their activity (laundry, dishes, work, etc.)  I'm not sure how much actvity you are having but someone said that moving your arms too much can create more vascular fluid. Yesterday, my wife just sat and watched TV all day and her drainage cut in half.  Route53 http://route53.wordpress.com
Posts.Title: Removing Drains and Getting Pathology Report Route53 hostanut

Posts.Content: Sep 19, 2008 03:38PM - edited Sep 19, 2008 03:39PM by Route53 We just got back from visiting the plastic surgeon (day 10 post surgery).  BTW, he is head of plastic surgery at UCSF, a top 10 cancer center according to US News & World Report. Although we were at 30-35ccs for 3 straight days, he told us to hold off for another 4 days through the weekend before removing the drains. He said that even after he takes the drains out the body can absorb about 30ccs a day naturally.  If you lay dormant for a few days and reduce the fluid release to below 30ccs the fluid emitters will seal themselves (you are giving them time to heal and dry up) and thus if the drains are taken out and you resume some light activity your fluid emission should not increase again and cause infections as have been documented by others in this thread.  Route53 http//route53.wordpress.com
Posts.Title: Removing Drains and Getting Pathology Report Route53 hostanut

Posts.Content: Sep 17, 2008 10:36AM Route53 wrote: Yes, we got results back that both nodes came back clear in the pathology report.  My wife took the call and she was told that the margins were still close but she'd let us speak to the head oncologist about if we'd like to have some light chemo (not exactly sure what that means).  They will go back in during the reconstruction swap and scrape more tissue away as well.  So we'll get the full path report tomorrow when we go in for our first post-surgery visit.  I don't think the drains will get pulled out as the fluid increased 10ccs more yesterday from the previous day. Do they stitch you up after they take out the drain?  Sounds weird.  I'm not sure I even want to look at how and where it goes in (I'm a visually squeamish person). Route53 http://route53.wordpress.com
Posts.Title: Removing Drains and Getting Pathology Report Route53 hostanut

Posts.Content: Oct 15, 2009 11:53AM Route53 wrote: My wife's surgical teams said that they just didn't want to her to have any issues with the anaesthesia.  She has had bad issues with nausea,  So whether she had an 8am or a 3pm surgery they have this blanket rule.  On her latest surgery which actually turned out to be 4pm they did tell her she could take some sips of liquid to help her swallow her tamoxifin and other medications. Not sure what type of Blue Shield coverage you have, but my wife's group in San Francisco takes it. If after your surgery you are unhappy with your oncologist I've met several couples over the past year  who commute long distances (Lake Tahoe, Fresno, and Hawaii) for their treatments. Good luck with your surgery. Erik (Route53) http://route53.wordpress.com

Posts.Title: Moving Back to Bed with Hubby hostanut Massgirl
